The present work investigates the steam reforming of butanol – ethanol mixtures for H2 production over Ru-based catalysts. Α 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 and a 5 wt% Ru/MgO-Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized via the wet impregnation method and physicochemically characterized with various techniques. Catalytic activity tests were carried out using a ButOH/EtOH/H2O mixture between 550 and 700 °C. The ButOH and EtOH conversion as well as H2 selectivity were found to be equal to ca. 100 % for all tested catalysts at 700 °C. The superior performance of Ru/Al2O3 compared to its Ru/MgO-Al2O3 counterpart was mainly attributed to the higher Ru metal dispersion achieved in the former case. The presence of MgO appears to suppress the H2 selectivity in favor of hydrocarbon reaction intermediates production. The higher activity and H2 selectivity of the Ru/Al2O3 is accompanied by remarkable stability after 45 h of exposure to the reaction mixture at 700 °C. Our work suggests that Ru-based catalysts may outperform Pt-based ones in technically challenging steam reforming processes involving alcohol mixtures toward H2 production. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Steam reforming H2 Butanol Ethanol Ru Pt Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen is a clean fuel with a high energy content produced from a variety of resources including natural gas, nuclear power, biomass and renewable power (e.g. solar, wind etc.). The most common methods applied today for H2 production are hydrocarbons (typically natural gas) reforming, electrolytic (often solar driven) and biological processes [1]. H2 produced via electrolysis can result in zero pollutant emissions, depending on the applied electricity source. However, given that the process requires high power input, the scientific and policy-making communities are rather skeptical concerning the cost as well as the efficiency of the electrolysis process. Solar driven processes exhibit low yields of H2 production. The thermal processes employed for hydrocarbons reforming require large amounts of heat as well as large amounts of catalytic materials, while the as produced H2-rich gas stream contains substantial quantities of byproducts which require further purification processes (water gas shift, methanation, CO oxidation etc.). However, the reforming processes, separated typically to steam reforming (SR), dry reforming (DR) and partial oxidation (POΧ) processes [2] or combinations of them like the oxidative steam reforming (OSR) process [3], are considered as the most efficient and effective ways for H2 production due to their high performance and their relatively lower cost compared to the other methods mentioned earlier [2,4]. SR is widely applied for H2 production employing various biomass-derived compounds such as ethanol (EtOH) [2,5]. Over the past decades EtOH gained significant interest as potential feedstock for H2 production. This was attributed, among other reasons such as the high energy content, to the renewable production of EtOH via the biomass fermentation (bio-EtOH) [6]. EtOH SR for H2 production is a highly endothermic reaction (Eq. 1, [5]) requiring high temperatures for high H2 yields [7]. (1) C 2 H 5 OH + 3 Η 2 Ο → 2 C O 2 + 6 H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 173.5 kJ mol − 1 The consumption of large amounts of energy in order EtOH to be effectively catalyzed towards H2 require the use of supported metal catalysts which is a common strategy as reported by Palma et al. [8]. However, the reaction network of EtOH SR comprises of various reactions running simultaneously producing, except from H2, various compounds such as carbon oxides, methane or ethylene [7]. The most significant reactions occurring in parallel with EtOH SR are the EtOH decomposition to CO, CH4 and H2 (Eq. 2), the syn gas (CO + H2) synthesis reaction (Eq. 3), the EtOH dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde (Eq. 4), the exothermic Boudouard reaction resulting in coke formation (Eq. 5), the exothermic methanation reaction (Eqs. 6 & 7) and the exothermic water gas shift (WGS) reaction (Eq. 8) which in the case that occurs reversely (reverse water gas shift, RWGS) is mildly endothermic (Eq. 9) [9–11]: (2) C 2 H 5 OH → CO + CH 4 + H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 49 kJ mol − 1 (3) C 2 H 5 OH + H 2 O → 2 CO + 4 H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 256 kJ mol − 1 (4) C 2 H 5 OH → C 2 H 4 O + H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 68 kJ mol − 1 (5) 2 CO → CO 2 + C , Δ Η 298 0 = − 171 kJ mol − 1 (6) 3 H 2 + CO → CH 4 + H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = − 206 kJ mol − 1 (7) 4 H 2 + CO → CH 4 + 2 H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = − 165 kJ mol − 1 (8) CO + H 2 O → C O 2 + H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = − 41 kJ mol − 1 (9) C O 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = + 41 kJ mol − 1 The high temperatures required for the EtOH SR often results in rapid catalytic deactivation, mostly attributed to coke formation [12] based on some of the abovementioned reactions. Despite the high efficiency that exhibit towards C-C and C-H bond cleavages of EtOH and the relatively much lower cost compared to noble metals, nickel based catalytic systems are prone to coke formation [8]. For this reason the use of noble metal (Rh, Pt, Pd, Ru, Ir) with low loadings (wt%) supported on various supports (Al2O3, CeO2, MgO) as potential catalysts for low temperature SR (LTSR) of EtOH is a common strategy [7,12,13]. Supported precious metal catalysts have been also applied for high temperature SR (HTSR) of EtOH [12]. Worth mentioning is the work of Liguras et al. [14] examining the performance towards HTSR of EtOH (600 – 850 °C) for H2 production of series of noble metal (Rh, Ru, Pt, Pd) supported (Al2O3, MgO, TiO2) catalysts. Among others Pt based catalytic materials exhibit enhanced performance towards the LTSR of EtOH promoting WGS reaction to CO2 and H2 thus reducing the CO levels [7]. The latter may facilitate the H2-rich reformate gas stream production process to feed proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), which are extremely sensitive even at very low CO concentration, since it reduces the cost of the purification steps applied for CO removal (WGS, methanation of CO, preferential oxidation of CO) that follows the EtOH SR step [7]. The majority of the published work on alcohol reforming for the production of H2-rich reformate gas streams focuses on low molecular weight alcohols such as methanol (MeOH) or EtOH [8,15,16]. The research on reforming processes of higher molecular weight alcohols, like butanol (ButOH) or propanol, has been left in the margins [8]. ButOH as a potential feedstock for reforming processes for H2 production has higher H2 content (13.51 wt%) compared to EtOH or MeOH which is reflected in higher heating value than other alcohols [8,15,16]. Specifically, the heating value of ButOH, EtOH and MeOH is equal to 32.12, 21.6 and 13.36 MJ kg−1, respectively, as reported by Okoro et al. [17]. Moreover, ButOH is less volatile than lighter alcohols (MeOH, EtOH) whereas the lower autoignition temperature value of the former compared to the latter facilitates the fuel ignition when butanol is mixed with gasoline or diesel fuel in internal combustion engines [8,15,16]. Furthermore, ButOH is easily blended with other fuels (gasoline, diesel, etc.) thus easing the production of fuels with higher energy content [8,15,16]. The low vapor pressure of ButOH makes it safer to handle than other potential fuels for high temperature reforming (HTR) processes whereas the less corrosive nature eases its distribution [8,15,16]. As in the case of bio-EtOH, ButOH can be derived via biomass fermentation process (bio-ButOH) [18–20]. Despite the aforementioned advantages of ButOH as a fuel, there is only a limited number of publications addressing the production of H2 via the reforming of ButOH. Various reforming processes (SR [21–27], DR [28], PROX [29], OSR [30–32], autothermal reforming (ATR) [33], aqueous phase reforming (APR) [34]) were employed to derive H2 from ButOH. SR appeared far more promising mostly because of the enhanced H2 production compared to the other [15,16]. The ButOH SR process could be described by the following reaction network [30,35,36]: (10) C 4 H 10 O + 3 H 2 O → 4 CO + 8 H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 614 kJ mol − 1 (11) C 4 H 10 O + 7 H 2 O → 4 CO + 12 H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 447 kJ mol − 1 (12) C 4 H 10 O → CO + 2 C H 4 + H 2 + C , Δ Η 298 0 = 68 kJ mol − 1 (13) C H 4 → 2 H 2 + C , Δ Η 298 0 = 75 kJ mol − 1 (14) 2 CO → CO 2 + C , Δ Η 298 0 = − 171 kJ mol − 1 (15) 3 H 2 + CO → CH 4 + H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = − 207 kJ mol − 1 (16) 4 H 2 + CO → CH 4 + 2 H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = − 165 kJ mol − 1 (17) CO + H 2 O → C O 2 + H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = − 41 kJ mol − 1 (18) 2 CO + 2 H 2 → C O 2 + C H 4 , Δ Η 298 0 = − 249 kJ mol − 1 (19) C + 2 H 2 → C H 4 , Δ Η 298 0 = − 75 kJ mol − 1 (20) C H 4 + H 2 O → CO + 3 H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 207 kJ mol − 1 (21) C H 4 + C O 2 → 2 CO + 2 H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 249 kJ mol − 1 (22) CO + H 2 → C + H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = − 132 kJ mol − 1 (23) 2 CO + 2 H 2 → 2 C + 2 H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = − 264 kJ mol − 1 (24) C O 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = + 41 kJ mol − 1 (25) C + H 2 O → CO + H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 132 kJ mol − 1 (26) C 4 H 10 O → C 4 H 8 O + H 2 , Δ Η 298 0 = 88 kJ mol − 1 (27) C 4 H 8 O → CO + C H 4 + C 2 H 4 , Δ Η 298 0 = 107 kJ mol − 1 (28) C 2 H 4 → polymer → C + 2 H 2 H2, CO, CO2 and CH4 are the main products of ButOH SR [35]. The dehydration of ButOH may result in ethylene, propylene or butylene [37] whereas ButOH dehydrogenation could result in butyric aldehyde, methyl ketone or isopropyl alcohol [38]. Clearly, the ButOH SR reaction network is more complex as compared to the EtOH SR as it consists of more steps. However, the WGS, RWGS, methanation and Boudouard reaction steps are essentially the same. ButOH SR reaction (Eq. 11) is far more endothermic than the EtOH SR reaction (Eq. 1) requiring higher amounts of energy in order to be effectively catalyzed. The ButOH SR reaction has been mostly studied over Ni-based catalytic systems whereas some other works investigated Co-based catalysts [21–23,30,32,39,40]. The use of transition metal catalysts is accompanied by coke formation thus reducing drastically the catalytic efficiency [41]. As mentioned earlier in the case of EtOH SR a common strategy to avoid coke formation is the use of noble metal-based catalytic system which would allow the occurrence of the ButOH SR at milder temperature values. To the best of our knowledge the most notable works studying solely the ButOH SR towards H2 production over precious metal-based catalysts are those by Yadav et al. [41–43] and Harju et al. [25,26]. Briefly, SR and ATR of n-butanol were investigated employing a 0.5 wt% Rh/ZrO2 catalyst at relatively mild temperature values (500 – 700 °C) which exhibited remarkable performance in regard to H2 yield at 700 °C, while at lower temperatures catalytic deactivation due to coke formation was observed [26]. The same group investigated, also, the role of the intermediates (1-butene and butyraldehyde) in SR of n-butanol over the same catalyst at 500 °C and 700 °C [25]. However, the high cost of Rh even at low wt% loadings hampers its use as potential reforming catalyst thus paving the way for the utilization of relatively less expensive noble metals typically used in reforming reactions such as Ru [41]. A kinetic study performed by Yadav et al. [41] concerning ButOH SR over Ru/Al2O3 catalyst at low SR temperature (350 – 500 °C) was based on a series of Langmuir-Hinshelwood models considering the reaction occurring among the adsorbed surface reactants as the rate determining step (rds). The ButOH conversion achieved and the corresponding H2 yield, equal to 93.4 % and 0.61 mol/mol respectively, were quite promising. In addition, based on the enhanced performance towards H2 production from EtOH LTSR of Pt and Pd compared to Ru and Rh catalysts (all supported on Al2O3) as presented by Basagiannis et al. [44], Yadav et al. [42] investigated the ButOH LTSR (350 – 500 °C) over Al2O3 supported Pt and Pd catalytic systems. Valuable information concerning the reaction mechanism were obtained. Finally, the same group studied the effect of the promotion with a series of noble metals, namely Pt, Ru and Pd, in Ni-Cu/La2O3-MgO catalytic system on the obtained activity and selectivity of n-butanol SR reaction [43]. The best performance concerning both the n-butanol conversion (> 75 %) to H2 (> 70 %) and stability (25 h) was exhibited in the case of Pt promoted sample. Nonetheless, nearly all the studies related to SR of several organic molecules to produce H2-rich reformate gas streams are performed by applying model compounds to investigate reaction kinetics over selected catalytic systems for each organic molecule separately. However, various processes such as biomass pyrolysis or purification of biomass from tar consist of several steps with various organic molecules (alcohols, carboxylic acids, aldehydes, ketones) being present in the stream at the same time. The simultaneous reaction of organic molecules in a potential SR process has not been thoroughly investigated [45]. The latter could be attributed to the complexity of the potential biomass feedstock such as the bio-oil [21]. Garbarino et al. studied the SR of EtOH-phenol mixture, two organic molecules typically present in biomass derived tar, over a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst [45]. The authors achieved H2 yields in the range of 85 % which were obtained without evident deactivation of the catalyst. Alcohols such as MeOH, EtOH or ButOH are present in bio-oils and for this reason they could be selected as model compounds in catalytic SR investigations of bio-oils [21]. Bimbela et al. studied the SR of acetol and 1-butanol separately over Ni-based catalysts in a temperature range of 550 – 750 °C [21]. According to Oasmaa et al. [46] among the alcohols present in bio-oil, ButOH appears to be in excess increasing that way the scientific interest as it concerns its potential use for H2 production. Both from a technical but also from a scientific point of view, the simultaneous SR of ButOH with EtOH or MeOH is of major interest as it will elucidate competing effects between the two molecules in the SR reaction network. Furthermore, the industrial production of ethyl tert-butyl ether (ETBE) results in significant amounts of effluents rich in EtOH and tert-ButOH (TBA), widely used in chemical industry. Τhe recovery and separation of these two compounds in a high purity form is an important but rather demanding and expensive process [47]. Considering the above the EtOH-TBA-water mixture resulting from the industrial ETBE production could undergo SR to H2 production [20]. This process, typically implemented by Clostridium strain, has gained great attention due to the various substrates and lignocellulosic materials than can be used in order to be fermented [3]. The mixture produced via the ABE fermentation process consists, primarily, from H2O (60 wt%) and AcO – ButOH – EtOH mixture with a mass ratio equal to 3:6:1 [28]. AcO is 99.5 % recovered from the first distillation column whereas the remaining azeotropic EtOH – ButOH mixture with H2O requires extra distillation units in order to be separated in its constituents increasing dramatically the operational cost thus making the process economically unsustainable [3,20]. In consideration of the abovementioned information, EtOH – ButOH – H2O mixture could be considered as a potential green biofuel for H2 production [3]. To the best of our knowledge, only Kumar et al. [3] conducted a detailed research towards the thermodynamic analysis of OSR to H2 production employing EtOH – ButOH mixture derived from ABE fermentation. The information described to this point suggests that the EtOH – ButOH mixtures, which may be present in different proportions in various biomass feedstocks or in effluents derived from ETBE industrial synthesis or even in the recovery process that follows ABE fermentation, could be a potential high – yield H2 source. However, the relatively small number of publications investigating reforming processes of this mixture is attributed to the complexity that characterizes the study of the simultaneously occurring reforming reactions of the two alcohols as well as the possible interactions between them. Towards the direction of finding an efficient and sustainable process for H2-rich gas streams, the present work intends to elucidate the SR process of EtOH – ButOH mixture over Ru based catalysts. Two Ru-based catalytic systems were investigated, namely a 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 and a 5 wt% Ru/MgO-Al2O3 and compared with a 0.5 wt% Pt/Al2O3 standard. All catalysts were synthesized via wet impregnation method and physicochemically characterized by employing BET, FTIR, XPS, H2 chemisorption and XRD. The catalysts were tested towards the SR of EtOH – ButOH mixture in terms of activity, selectivity and stability they exhibit towards H2 production. To the best of our knowledge this is the first time that Ru based catalysts are examined concerning the SR of ButOH/EtOH mixture for H2 production. 2 Experimental 2.1 MgO-Al2O3 synthesis and catalyst preparation The MgO-Al2O3 support was synthesized via wet impregnation as described by Kousi et al. [48]. The appropriate amount of Magnesium dinitrate hexahydrate (99.999 % trace metals basis) Mg(NO3)2 6 H2O (Alfa Aesar) was dissolved in triple distilled water followed by the addition of appropriate amount of commercial γ-Al2O3 support (99.9 % purity, Alfa Products, Pell 1/8΄΄) under continuous stirring (the alumina pellets were grounded before use). The resulting suspension was continuous stirred at 40 °C under vacuum in a rotary evaporator device (Büchi) until the complete evaporation of the water. The solid residue was dried at 110 °C overnight and the resulting powder was calcined at 900 °C at static air for 16 h. The wt% loading of the MgO on Al2O3 was adjusted at 15 wt%. Three noble metal-based catalysts namely 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3, 5 wt% Ru/MgO-Al2O3 and 0.5 wt% Pt/Al2O3 were synthesized via the wet impregnation method [49]. The higher applied wt% loading of Ru samples compared to Pt was selected partly because of the much higher cost of the latter compared to that of the former. Nonetheless, another reason was that the 5 wt% Ru and the 0.5 wt% Pt loadings were employed in previous works of our laboratory thus facilitating the comparison of their catalytic performance with the corresponding performance of these catalysts presented in other studies [14,44,50,51]. The notation along with nominal formula of the synthesized catalysts are presented in Table 1. Briefly, metal precursor salts namely Ruthenium(III) nitrosylnitrate solution (Ru 1.5 % w/v) Ru(NO)(NO3)3 (Alfa Aesar), Diamminedinitritoplatinum(II) in ammonium hydroxide (NH3)2Pt(NO2)2 (99.9 % purity, Alfa Aesar) were diluted in triple distilled water under continuous stirring. Subsequently after the dissolution of the metal precursors appropriate amount of commercial γ-Al2O3 support (Alfa Products, Pell 1/8΄΄) was added in the mixture under stirring after being grounded in a mortar in the case of RuAl and PtAl catalytic systems. The same procedure was followed also in the case of RuMgAl catalyst with the addition of appropriate amount of synthesized MgO-Al2O3 support instead of γ-Al2O3. In all cases the slurry was heated gradually up to 70 °C and remained at this temperature until the complete evaporation of the water. The remained solid was dried at 110 °C overnight. The corresponding powder was reduced at 400 °C under H2 flow for 2 h in the case of RuAl and RuMgAl catalysts whereas the reduction temperature was adjusted at 300 °C (2 h under H2 flow) in the case of PtAl catalytic system. Based on previous works of our lab, these temperature values were found to be appropriate in order to assure the complete reduction of each metal [49,52,53]. 2.2 Physicochemical characterization Synthesized catalytic powders were examined concerning their specific surface area (SSA) via applying the N2 physisorption at liquid N2 temperature (−196 °C) via the B.E.T. method employing a Micromeritics (Gemini III 2375) instrument. Briefly, as it concerns the pre-treatment procedure, prior to each measurement, each sample was dried at 110 °C for 1 h, then weighed and placed into one of the two burettes used in the experimental process. Each sample was subsequently re-dried for ca. 30 min inside the burette. The burette was then fitted to the respective port of the device, after being transferred there from the dryer closed with a suitable cap in order to avoid contact with moisture. The as-prepared catalytic samples were investigated towards their structure via the X-ray diffraction (XRD) employing a Philips P (PW 1830/40) diffractometer whereas the analysis of the XRD spectra was performed applying appropriate software using JCPDS data files. Details of the aforementioned techniques can be found elsewhere [54]. The dispersion of the metal phase (Ru/Pt) on the support as well as the average metal crystallite size were determined via the H2 selective chemisorption technique employing a Fisons Instruments (Sorptomatic) 1900 apparatus described in detail by Panagiotopoulou et al. [49]. The measured aforementioned characteristics of the tested catalysts and supports are shown in Table 1. CO temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments on the catalytic surfaces were carried out applying in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy using a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer device. Information of the employed device are provided elsewhere [55]. Typically, the catalyst sample was heated under He flow (30 cm3 min−1) at 450 °C for 15 min and then reduced with 20 % H2 in He at 400 °C in the case of Ru-based catalysts and at 300 °C in the case of PtAl catalyst for 30 min. The flow was then switched to He and the temperature was increased at 450 °C. After 15 min at this temperature, the sample was cooled at room temperature. During the cooling stage, background spectra were recorded under He flow at the desired temperatures. The flow was switched to 1 % CO in He (30 cm3 min−1), and the first spectrum was recorded at 25 °C after 30 min on-stream. The flow was finally switched to He at 25 °C for 30 min. The temperature was then step-wise increased up to 450 °C, and spectra were obtained at the desired temperatures after equilibration for 5 min on-stream. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using a non-monochromatic AlKα line at 1486.6 eV and a Leybold LH EA11 electron energy analyzer operated at a constant pass energy of 100 eV and pressure 2 × 10−9 mbar. The catalyst powder was pressed on a thin lead sheet and the analyzed area was a 2 × 5 mm2 rectangle, placed near the center of the powder-covered area on each specimen surface. The C1s signal at 284.8 eV was used as a reference for sample charge correction. More information about the XPS measurements can be found in previous studies [56,57]. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests Catalytic performance measurements were conducted utilizing an apparatus consisting of an HPLC pump, a gas flow controlling system (mass-flow controllers), the reactor and an on-line analysis system (gas chromatographs, GCs). The ButOH/EtOH/H2O liquid mixture was pumped into the evaporator maintained at 230 °C employing the HPLC pump (Marathon II, Scientific Systems) and subsequently fed into the reactor through a fiberglass insulated stainless steel tubes maintained at 160 °C (1/8′’ O.D.), being previously adjusted with a mass flow controller (MKS). Moreover, the flow of the gas streams (He, H2) required for the catalytic pretreatment is controlled with the mass-flow controllers (MKS). The analysis of reactants and products was performed by two GCs (Shimadzu) connected in parallel equipped with appropriate analysis columns. A Shimadzu GC-9A, (using He as carrier gas) equipped with TCD and FID detectors was used for the separation of C4H10O, C2H6O, CH4, C2H6, C2H4, CH3CHO, C3H7 employing the 80/100 Porapak-Q column (6FT × 1/8in SS, SUPELCO), whereas the separation of CO, CO2 and CH4 products was carried out with the aid of the 100/120 Carbosieve SII column (10FT × 1/8in SS SUPELCO). A Shimadzu GC-8A, using N2 as carrier gas, equipped with a TCD detector was employed for the Η2 detection present in the resulting reformate gas stream using a 100/120 Carbosieve SII column (10FT × 1/8in SS SUPELCO). Details regarding the reactor, the thermocouple applied to measure the temperature inside the reactor as well as additional technical characteristics of the GCs can be found elsewhere [44]. All applied gasses were of high purity (99.999 %). Following a typical experimental procedure, 600 mg (0.18 < d < 0.25 mm) of fresh catalytic sample after placed in the reactor was subsequently in situ reduced at 400 °C (RuAl, RuMgAl) or 300 °C (PtAl) under H2 flow (40 cm3/min) for 2 h. The temperature was annealed to the desired value (400 or 300 °C) under He flow. After the reduction of the sample the temperature was subsequently increased, under He flow, at 700 °C and after achieving system equilibrium, the feed was switched to the ButOH/EtOH/H2O mixture. The concentration of the obtained ButOH/EtOH/H2O liquid solution fed into the HPLC pump was equal to 24.7 % / 14.7 % / 60.6 % corresponding to 6.9 % / 6.5 % / 86.6 % composition of gas stream obtained after the evaporator. The contact time was set in term of gas hour space velocity (GHSV) receiving a value of 13500 h−1. The composition was selected concerning the good solubility of EtOH in ButOH/H2O solution. The used EtOH (absolute ≥ 99.8 %, Honeywell) and ButOH (99.5 %, PENTA) were of high purity. Experimental conditions applied for the determination of the catalytic activity when ranging the reaction temperature for all tested samples and during stability tests were the same. ButOH and EtOH conversions were calculated via the following equations: (29) X ButOH = [ ButOH ] in − [ ButOH ] out [ ButOH ] in × 100 (30) X EtOH = [ EtOH ] in − [ EtOH ] out [ EtOH ] in × 100 where [ButOH]in, [EtOH]in and [ButOH]out, [EtOH]out are the inlet and outlet concentrations of ButOH and EtOH, respectively. The calculation of the selectivities of the obtained carbon-containing products and H2 were carried out using Eqs. (31) and (32), respectively as described by Ramantani et al. [58]: (31) S C i = [ C i ] × n Σ ( [ C i ] × n ) × 100 (32) S H 2 = [ Η 2 ] H 2 + Σ ( y 2 × C x H y i ) × 100 where [Ci] and [H2] denote the obtained concentration of each product i and the concentration of H2, respectively, while n corresponds to the number of carbon atoms of each product i. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterization The notation for the catalysts and supports used in this work together with their physicochemical characteristics as derived via the BET method and H2 selective chemisorption are summarized on Table 1. The specific surface area (SSA) obtained via the BET method revealed that the deposition of Ru on the Al2O3 support resulted in a reduction of the SSA value from ca. 80 m2 g−1 to ca. 70 m2 g−1. The latter was also observed in the case of the deposition of Ru onto the MgAl support. However, in the case of Pt deposition on the Al support the SSA value increased from 80 m2 g−1 to ca. 93 m2 g−1. The differences in the SSA between the Ru based catalysts and Pt one is understood in terms of the metal loading which was much lower for the PtAl catalyst (0.5 wt% Pt) compared to RuAl and RuMgAl catalysts (5 wt% Ru). It is worth noting, that the SSA values of the RuAl (70.2 m2 g−1) and RuMgAl (80.1 m2 g−1) appear to be smaller than the corresponding SSAs obtained by Kousi et al. [48], which is most likely related to the higher reduction temperature used in this work (400 °C) as compared to 350 °C used by the aforementioned research team [59]. The H2 selective chemisorption measurements show that the PtAl catalyst display higher dispersion of the active metal phase as compared to the Ru based catalytic systems. The higher dispersion of Pt is also reflected on the smaller average crystallite size (1.2 nm) compared to the Ru crystallite size. The latter observations are strongly related to the higher wt% Ru loading as well as the higher reduction temperature of the Ru based catalysts (400 °C) which lead to the formation of larger metal nanoparticles. The dispersion of Ru metal was smaller in the case of RuMgAl compared to that obtained for the RuAl catalyst. This is in accordance with the observations made by Kousi et al. [48]. XRD spectra obtained for the synthesized catalysts and supports are depicted in Fig. 1. XRD measurements were recorded over fresh catalytic systems as received after the reduction process. In the case of alumina supported materials (Fig. 1A) crystallographic reflections at 2θ equal to 37.57°, 45.79°, 60.84° and 66.76° attributed to (110), (111), (210) and (211) planes of Al2O3 (JCPDS Card No. 1–1303) were detected. The small peak detected in the diffractogram of RuAl at 2θ= 44.4° is attributed to the (101) crystallographic plane of hexagonal Ru. Crystallographic peaks attributed to MgAl2O4 (JCPDS Card No. 1–1157) spinel were detected in the diffractogram of RuMgAl (Fig. 1B). Some of the peaks corresponding to MgAl2O4 phase overlap with crystallographic peaks of Al2O3 (JCPDS Card No. 1–1303) implying the coexistence of both phases in the RuMgAl sample. Crystallographic peaks attributed to Al2O3 were detected in the XRD spectrum of the synthesized MgAl support (Fig. 1B). The above observations concerning the Ru based materials are in close agreement with the XRD patterns and relevant analysis reported by Kousi et al. [48] where the absence of intense crystallographic peaks attributed to Ru0 was related to the fine Ru dispersion on the support. The in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) spectra obtained following the interaction of CO with PtAl, RuAl, and RuMgAl catalysts are presented in Fig. 2. CO in addition of being a reaction product in the present case, it is also an excellent molecule used to study the nature and strength of active sites. As shown in Fig. 2A, exposure of PtAl catalyst to CO at 25 °C for 30 min (a) resulted in the appearance of bands located at ca. 2171, 2065 and 1833 cm−1. The band located at 2171 cm−1, which disappeared on switching to He for 30 min, may be safely attributed to gas-phase CO. The bands located at 2065 and 1833 cm−1 are characteristic of linear and bridge-bonded CO on reduced platinum sites (Pt0), respectively [60]. Switching the feed to He results in the decrease of the intensity of the 1833 cm−1 band, which disappears when the sample is heated above 100 °C as shown in Fig. 2A (traces c-f). The band attributed to linear CO, although it appears to be thermally more stable, it also declines in intensity with increasing sample temperature, shifting at the same time from 2065 to 2045 cm−1 until its complete disappearance at temperatures above 250 °C [61]. DRIFT spectra obtained over the RuAl catalyst are shown in Fig. 2B. The spectrum recorded in the presence of CO (trace a) is characterized by bands in the ν(CO) region, which are attributed to carbonyl species adsorbed on Ru. The bands located at 2132 and 2078 cm−1 can be assigned to two types of carbonyl species on partially oxidized Ru sites (Run+(CO)x) [62,63]. The band located at 2026 cm−1 is a broad peak and is attributed to linear CO adsorbed on reduced Ru crystallites [62]. Switching the feed to He and increase of temperature does not affect the intensity or location of bands attributed to carbonyl species on Run+. However, at 300 °C the Rux-CO band broadens and shifts from 2026 to 2017 and 2006 cm−1. In marked contrast to the PtAl catalyst, the carbonyl species on the RuAl appear to be more strongly adsorbed. The DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed on the RuMgAl sample are displayed in Fig. 2C. Bands at approximately 2054 cm−1 are observed as the result of linearly adsorbed CO on metallic Ru while bands typical of Run+(CO)x carbonyls appear at 2127, 2095, and 2066 cm−1 [64]. The carbonyl peaks are of lower intensity, compared to RuAl catalyst, and a new CO adsorption band appears around 2108 cm−1 [65]. These differences indicate that CO is less strongly adsorbed on RuMgAl catalyst. This was verified by the decrease and the disappearance of the peaks upon increasing the temperature to 150 °C (trace d). XPS was further utilized to study the surface composition and the chemical state of the individual components present on the plain support and on the catalysts. In all cases the samples have been pre-reduced prior XPS measurements under H2 flow for 2 h. The reduction temperature was 400 °C and 300 °C in the case of Ru-based samples and PtAl catalyst, respectively. The spectra shown in Fig. 3a correspond to the Al2s-Al2p XPS region of (i) the Al2O3 and (ii) MgO-Al2O3 supports, which where used as reference spectra, as well as the (iii) RuAl, (iv) RuMgAl, and (v) PtAl catalysts. In all cases, both the Al2p and Al2s peaks are located at binding energies of 74.1 and 119 ± 0.1 eV, while the Al KLL peak is found at 99 ± eV, which are the typical binding energies of the Al+3 oxidation state. The presence of magnesium is confirmed by the Mg2s peak at an energy of 88.6 ± 0.1 eV corresponding to the Mg+2 oxidation state [66]. Fig. 3b shows the spectra of the O1s region for the five samples. The O1s exhibits a relatively broad signal centered at approximately 531 eV which correspond to surface lattice oxygen (Olat) species. The shoulder at 532.2 eV on the O1s peak is most likely associated with surface hydroxyl species (O(-OH)). It is worth noting that the aluminum and magnesium lattice oxygen species exhibit similar binding energies and therefore cannot be clearly resolved. Fig. 3c shows the Ru3p3/2 signals for the RuAl (iii) and RuMgAl (iv) samples. In both cases the Ru3p3/2 is centered at 461.2 ± 0.1 eV, which is typical for ruthenium in the metallic state [67]. The Pt 4 f signal for the Fig. 3d finally shows that traces of Pt are at energies of 70.8 and 74.1 close to what is expected for metallic Pt [68,69]. The quantitative information obtained from the XPS measurements is displayed in Table 2. Clearly, increasing the concentration of Mg leads to a drop in the atomic ratio O/Al (Table 2), indicating that magnesium is mostly found on the surface of alumina. The higher dispersion of Ru on Al2O3 surface compared to the corresponding dispersion of Ru on MgO-Al2O3 surface, as obtained via selective chemisorption (Table 1) is reflected on the higher Ru atomic ratio in the case of the former as obtained via XPS measurements (Table 2). There is no evidence of synergistic effect between the Ru and Pt metals over the supports as obtained from the analysis of the FTIR and XPS measurements. However, this was expected since Al2O3 support is considered an inactive metal oxide support which is typically applied in order to provide a high surface area for the metal particles deposition. The latter enhances the metal dispersion and subsequently the number of exposed catalytically active metal sites. 3.2 Catalytic performance The SR of the ButOH/EtOH mixture was studied between 550 °C and 700 °C to achieve the maximum selectivity towards H2. The used temperature range was selected after experiments conducted in an empty reactor (homogeneous reactions) in order to investigate the temperatures where the homogeneous activity towards ButOH-EtOH reforming mixture was becoming significant. It was found that homogeneous activity was becoming important for temperatures above 750 °C. Furthermore, in order to achieve relatively higher conversions as well as higher H2 selectivity it was decided to conduct the experiments above 500 °C. Considering the above the temperature range was adjusted at 550 – 700 °C. As described by Yadav et al. [42] the dehydrogenation of ButOH (Eq. 26) results in butyraldehyde (C4H8O) formation on the catalyst’s surface followed by C-C bond cleavage leading to CO formation. The latter undergoes WGS reaction to form H2 and CO2 (Eq. 8). However, the H2 production via this reaction pathway is more complex than the direct thermal decomposition of ButOH (Eq. 12) favored at higher temperatures. Moreover, increasing the reaction temperature decreases the selectivity towards C4H8O but increases the selectivity towards H2 and CO2 (WGS) [42]. Conversely, the thermal decomposition of ButOH at lower temperatures is accompanied by the formation of CH4, CO and C [42] hampering this way the selectivity towards H2. Based on this information and also taking into account that H2, CO, CO2 and CH4 are the only products obtained for EtOH SR over noble metal based catalysts at temperature higher than 527 °C [70], the SR of the ButOH/EtOH mixture was examined at temperature higher than 550 °C. ButOH and EtOH conversion vs. applied temperature over the RuAl catalytic system is presented in Fig. 4A. Above 650 °C the conversion of both reactants is complete whereas a slight reduction is observed at lower temperature values. The high conversion rate (above 90 %) in the examined temperature range (550 – 700 °C) implies that the RuAl catalyst exhibits high activity towards the SR of ButOH/EtOH/H2O mixture. Fig. 4B displays the products selectivity for the reaction over the RuAl catalyst as calculated based on Eqs. (31) and (32). The selectivity towards H2 increases with increasing temperature exhibiting values above 95 % at ca. 700 °C. The selectivity of CO2 is higher at lower temperatures compared to the corresponding selectivity of CO implying the occurrence of WGS (Eq. 8) whereas above ca. 680 °C the selectivity towards CO overcomes the CO2 selectivity denoting the occurrence of RWGS (Eq. 9) which is favored at elevated temperatures [71]. Finally, the RuAl catalyst is not selective towards CH4 with its selectivity value being ca. 0 % in the entire examined temperature range. The CH4 produced via the mildly endothermic EtOH decomposition reaction (49 kJ/mol) and ButOH decomposition reaction (68 kJ/mol) described by the Eqs. 2 and 12, respectively, as well as the exothermic methanation reaction (Eqs. 6,7) undergoes SR reaction (Methane Steam Reforming, MSR) to syngas production (Eq. 20) thus increasing H2 yield furtherly. This is corroborated by results presented by Jia et al. [72] studying EtOH SR over Ir/CeO2 catalyst. The performance stability of the RuAl catalyst was examined at 700 °C for ca. 45 h. The products selectivity as a function of reaction time is illustrated in Fig. 5. H2 selectivity remained above 95 % after 45 h of continuous reaction demonstrating highly efficient catalytic performance towards SR of ButOH/EtOH mixture. CO selectivity was higher than the CO2 selectivity implying the occurrence of RWGS reaction as mentioned earlier for temperature values above 680 °C. Whereas the practically zero selectivity towards CH4 suggests the existence of an MSR reaction pathway on the catalyst surface favored by the relatively elevated temperature (700 °C) as already mentioned. Although high SSA Al2O3 is often applied as a catalyst support to assist high dispersion of the active metal phase [73], a major drawback with its use is that it facilitates coke deposition on the active phase due to polymerization, dehydration or cracking reactions occurring on its acid sites [74]. In this respect the use of basic promoters like MgO or CaO can favor the WGS reaction by increasing the basic sites on the catalytic surface which facilitate CO adsorption and H2O dissociation and consequently reduce CH4 formation [75]. To the best of our knowledge only Menezes et al. [73] studied alkaline earth metal oxides on γ-alumina as supports for Ni-based catalyst towards ButOH SR. In order to study the effect of basic sites on the ButOH/EtOH SR reaction, MgO oxide was used as a promoter of the Al2O3 support for a 5 wt% Ru catalyst (RuMgAl). The ButOH and EtOH conversion and products selectivity over the RuMgAl catalyst as a function of temperature are shown in Figs. 6 and 7, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6A the ButOH conversion is complete for the examined temperature range (550 – 700 °C). However, the EtOH conversion appears to be below 60% for temperature values lower than 600 °C followed by a steep increase immediately after 620 °C achieving 100 % conversion at ca. 700 °C. The latter could be attributed to byproducts formation with the general formula C4Hx (Fig. 6B) demonstrating the products selectivity depends strongly on temperature. It is worth mentioning, that the retention time of the C4Hx byproduct is almost the same with that of EtOH hampering this way the detection of EtOH. For this reason, samples were obtained via a condenser and were analyzed with GCMS where the identification analysis was carried out. The C4Hx and EtOH concentration reduce with increasing temperature following the same trend. The most probable scenario is that this byproduct is derived by a side reaction of ButOH and could be butane. The reduction of the C4Hx concentration is reflected on the reduction of its selectivity with increasing temperature as presented in Fig. 6B. The selectivity of the desired H2 product increases with increasing temperature from ca. 40 % at 550 °C to ca. 90 % at 700 °C implying high catalytic selectivity at high temperature. The selectivity of CO and CO2 follow the same pattern as in the case of RuAl catalyst (Fig. 4B). At temperature values above 680 °C the CO exhibited slightly higher selectivity than the corresponding selectivity obtained for CO2 inferring the occurrence of RWGS reaction at elevated temperatures whereas at lower temperatures WGS reaction is favored. The selectivity of methane is ca. zero in the entire examined temperature range with a small increment observed at temperature values above 650 °C. Moreover, the RuMgAl catalyst exhibited a small selectivity towards C2H4 equal to ca. 15 % at 550 °C which further dropped with increasing temperature reaching zero above 630 °C. Ethylene could be produced via the exothermic EtOH dehydration reaction (Eq. 33) favored under EtOH SR conditions over metal catalysts supported on carriers with acid sites as described by Basagiannis et al. [44]: (29) C 2 H 5 OH → C 2 H 4 + H 2 O , Δ Η 298 0 = − 45.3 kJ mol − 1 An alternative reaction pathway for ethylene production could be via the Eqs. 26 and 27 showing the ButOH decomposition to C4H8O and the subsequent decomposition of butyraldehyde to CO, CH4 and C2H4. It is very likely that both processes occur without, however, being able to quantify the contribution rate of each one separately towards the production of C2H4. The products selectivity as a function of time obtained at 700 °C for the RuMgAl catalytic system is depicted in Fig. 7. The results are qualitative the same with those derived for the RuAl catalyst (Fig. 5). The RuMgAl exhibited high selectivity (above 95 %) for ca. 45 h of continuous reaction whereas the selectivity of CO was above 50 % during the stability test higher than the corresponding selectivity value of CO2 which was ca. 40 %. The selectivity of C2H4 and C4Hx were practically zero whereas the CH4 selectivity was below 5 % corroborating the small increase of the methane selectivity observed above 650 °C mentioned earlier (Fig. 6B). In order to compare the performance towards SR of ButOH/EtOH for H2 production over the Ru-based catalysts with a catalytic material typically employed for reforming reactions, an Al2O3 supported Pt-based catalyst (PtAl) was synthesized via the wet impregnation and its catalytic performance was examined under the same conditions. Reactant conversion and products selectivity versus applied temperature are demonstrated in Fig. 8A and B, respectively. ButOH conversion was complete in the 550 – 700 °C temperature range while EtOH conversion was above 85 % becoming complete at 700 °C (Fig. 8A). The observed selectivity of H2 was relatively low (40 %) and increases with temperature achieving 100 % at 700 °C (Fig. 8B). The behavior of CO and CO2 was qualitative the same with that observed in Ru-based catalysts with the RWGS reaction being favored at elevated temperature (above 680 °C) and the WGS being promoted at temperatures below 680 °C. PtAl was slightly selective towards C2H4 product at temperatures lower than 640 °C whereas the selectivity of CH4 vs. temperature showed a maximum around 660 °C (6.2 %). In regard to the C2H4 and CH4 selectivity, this trend could be explained by the reactions mentioned earlier in the case of RuMgAl catalyst. C3Hx byproduct formation was detected with its concentration reducing with increasing temperature as in the case of the C4Hx byproduct formed over RuMgAl catalyst. Fig. 9 shows the stability performance test of PtAl expressed via the dependence of the products selectivity by reaction time. The catalytic performance of PtAl reference material was rather unstable. H2 selectivity was equal to ca. 96 % at the beginning of the measurements reaching 87 % after 4.5 h of reaction at 700 °C. After 5 h under continuous reaction conditions, mediated by an overnight pause denoted by the vertical dashed line, H2 selectivity was equal to 92 % ending to 82 % after 7.5 h. The RWGS reaction appears to take place for ca. 8 h. After 8 h the CO2 selectivity increased to a higher level compared to the corresponding CO selectivity. This was accompanied by an increase in the C3Hx byproduct selectivity implying the occurrence of various side reactions. The observed increase in the C3Hx concentration resulted in a decrease in the corresponding H2 concentration. The latter is reflected on the selectivity values of these products as shown in Fig. 9. Since the selectivity towards H2 production was lower than 90 % in the case of PtAl catalyst obtained under the same experimental conditions as in the case of Ru-based catalysts, the stability test was finalized after ca. 12 h of exposure to the reaction mixture. As it concerns the ethylene formation over the examined catalytic surfaces, the only case that C2H4 was not detected as a reaction product was over the RuAl catalyst. This implies that either the EtOH or/and ButOH decomposition reactions, such as EtOH dehydration, do not occur on RuAl surface or they are taking place rapidly. The former is more probable since the RuAl catalyst exhibited the highest selectivity towards H2 without the formation of any byproduct accompanied by remarkable stability. If these reactions were taking place fast on the RuAl surface this could result partly in enhanced H2 yield but also in catalytic deactivation due to reaction described by Eq. 28. The detection of C4Hx and C3Hx products in the case of RuMgAl and PtAl catalysts, could be attributed to the ButOH decomposition reactions. The C4Hx and C3Hx could be considered as intermediate species for the formation of reforming products (H2 and carbon oxides) and could be derived by ButOH dehydration on Al2O3 acid sites [25]. In the case of RuMgAl catalyst the potential formation of butyraldehyde could be due to the ButOH dehydrogenation reaction on the Ru sites or MgO basic sites [25]. All the detected byproducts (C4Hx, C3Hx, C2Hx species) may or may not contribute to carbon accumulation on catalytic surface and subsequent catalyst deactivation. In the case of PtAl catalytic system the high selectivity of C3Hx species and C2H4 could partly explain the rapid catalytic deactivation after 12 h of exposure to the reaction mixture. On the contrary the formation of C4Hx species and C2H4 on the RuMgAl surface did not affect the catalytic stability. The latter could be related to the presence of MgO which may facilitate the potential carbon gasification which was formed under reaction conditions on the catalytic surface [76]. Studies investigating the reforming processes over mixtures of alcohols and hydrocarbons are relatively few, as mentioned earlier in Introduction section, whereas the employed processes differ significantly. For this reason, the direct comparison of the catalytic performance of the materials tested in other works related to SR of various mixtures with the most active RuAl system demonstrated in the present study would be rather misleading. The superior performance of the RuAl catalyst compared to RuMgAl catalytic system could be attributed to the higher dispersion and smaller particle size of Ru over the Al2O3 support as compared to the MgO-Al2O3 support (Table 1). These observations are consistent with the XPS measurements showing a higher Ru atomic ratio on the catalyst surface in the case of RuAl (Table 2). The larger number of Ru atoms present on the catalytic surface in the case of RuAl compared to RuMgAl favored the ButOH and EtOH decomposition reactions thus increasing H2 selectivity. Considering the above, among the three catalytic systems examined for the reforming of EtOH-ButOH mixture, the RuAl catalytic system exhibited the highest activity and selectivity towards H2 production whereas its stability after 45 h of exposure to reaction mixture at 700 °C was remarkable. 4 Conclusions Two Ru-based catalysts (5 wt%) were deposited on Al2O3 and MgO-Al2O3 supports via the wet impregnation method and 0.5 wt% Pt/Al2O3 was also prepared via the same method in order to be used as a reference material. The structural and electronic characteristics of the synthesized materials were investigated with a variety of techniques. Comparing the Ru based catalysts, the 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 exhibited the highest metal dispersion (21 %) and the smallest average crystallite size (4.7 nm) as derived from H2 selective chemisorption measurements. The 5 wt% Ru/MgO-Al2O3 exhibited larger specific surface area (87.2 m2 g−1) compared to that obtained for the Al2O3 supported sample (70 m2 g−1). The CO was adsorbed more strongly on the 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 surface as obtained after the CO-TPD measurements using FTIR spectroscopy whereas the XPS measurements revealed the higher atomic percentage of Ru on the catalytic surface of the Ru/Al2O3 compared to the MgO-Al2O3 supported catalyst. The catalytic activity towards the steam reforming of ButOH-EtOH mixture was studied using a ButOH/EtOH/H2O mixture of 6.9 % / 6.5 % / 86.6 % in the temperature range of 550–700 °C. The ButOH conversion was ca. 100 % over the entire examined temperature range for all the tested materials. The conversion of EtOH was higher than 90 % over the entire temperature range only in the case of the 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 sample. The H2 selectivity was higher in the case of the bare Al2O3 supported Ru based catalyst. It is worth mentioning that this catalyst displayed remarkable stability without the formation of byproducts. The formation of C4Hx and C3Hx products in the case of 5 wt% Ru/MgO-Al2O3 and 0.5 wt% Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively, could be attributed to the ButOH decomposition reactions. The high selectivity towards C3Hx species and C2H4 resulted in a rapid deactivation after 12 h of exposure to reaction mixture in the case of the Pt-based sample whereas the byproducts formation in the case of Ru/MgO-Al2O3 catalyst did not seem to hamper the catalytic stability. The enhanced catalytic activity of the Ru/Al2O3 compared to Ru/MgO-Al2O3 may be attributed to the higher dispersion of Ru over the Al2O3 compared to that obtained for the MgO-Al2O3 supported catalyst. A higher number of Ru atoms were present on the catalytic surface in the case of the Ru/Al2O3 system thus favoring ButOH and EtOH decomposition reactions resulting in higher H2 selectivity. coredata.dc:description: The present work investigates the steam reforming of butanol – ethanol mixtures for H2 production over Ru-based catalysts. Α 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 and a 5 wt% Ru/MgO-Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized via the wet impregnation method and physicochemically characterized with various techniques. Catalytic activity tests were carried out using a ButOH/EtOH/H2O mixture between 550 and 700 °C. The ButOH and EtOH conversion as well as H2 selectivity were found to be equal to ca. 100 % for all tested catalysts at 700 °C. The superior performance of Ru/Al2O3 compared to its Ru/MgO-Al2O3 counterpart was mainly attributed to the higher Ru metal dispersion achieved in the former case. The presence of MgO appears to suppress the H2 selectivity in favor of hydrocarbon reaction intermediates production. The higher activity and H2 selectivity of the Ru/Al2O3 is accompanied by remarkable stability after 45 h of exposure to the reaction mixture at 700 °C. Our work suggests that Ru-based catalysts may outperform Pt-based ones in technically challenging steam reforming processes involving alcohol mixtures toward H2 production.
coredata.dc:title: Steam reforming of butanol-ethanol mixture for H2 production over Ru catalysts
